title: Smartphone addiction
intro: Are you a phubber? Do you suffer from FOMO? These are words associated with smartphone addiction. 6 Minute English describes these words and discusses how you can kick the habit.
this_week_question: In what year did the term ‘smartphone’ first appear in print? Was it: a) 1995 b) 2000 c) 2005
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: person who ignores the real people around them because they are concentrating on their phones
having a physical or mental need to keep on doing something compulsively unable to stop doing something again and again

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hello, welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Rob.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: And I'm Catherine.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So, Catherine, how long do you spend on your smartphone?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: My smartphone? Not that long really, only about 18 or 19 hours.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: No, sorry, I meant in a day, not in a week.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Er, that's what I meant too, Rob – a day.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Oh wow, so you’ve even got it right here…

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: …yep, got it now, Rob. Yes, I should tell you that I suffer from FOMO.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: FOMO ?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: FOMO - Fear of Missing Out. Something cool or interesting might be happening somewhere, Rob, and I want to be sure I catch it, so I have to keep checking my phone, to make sure, you know, I don’t miss out on anything.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So we could call you a phubber … Hello… I said, so you’re a phubber ? Someone who ignores other people because you’d rather look at your phone.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Oh, yeah, that's right.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: It sounds like you have a bit of a problem there, Catherine. But you’re not the only one. According to one recent survey, half of teenagers in the USA feel like they are addicted to their mobile phones. If you are addicted to something, you have a physical or mental need to keep on doing it. You can’t stop doing it. You often hear about people being addicted to drugs or alcohol, but you can be addicted to other things too, like mobile phones. So, Catherine, do you think you’re addicted to your phone? How long could you go without it? Catherine? Catherine!

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Sorry, Rob, yes, well I think if I went more than a minute, I'd probably get sort of sweaty palms and I think I'd start feeling a bit panicky.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Oh dear! Well, if I can distract you for a few minutes, can we look at this topic in more detail please? Let's start with a quiz question first though. In what year did the term ‘smartphone’ first appear in print? Was it:

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: OK, you've got my full attention now, Rob, and I think it’s 2000, but actually can I just have a quick look on my phone to check the answer?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: No, no, that would be cheating – for you – maybe not for the listeners.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Spoilsport.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Right, Jean Twenge is a psychologist who has written about the damage she feels smartphones are doing to society. She has written that smartphones have probably led to an increase in mental health problems for teenagers. We’re going to hear from her now, speaking to the BBC. What does she say is one of the dangers of using our phones?

transcript.author: Jean Twenge, psychologist and author
transcript.text: I think everybody’s had that experience of reading their news feed too much, compulsively checking your phone if you’re waiting for a text or getting really into social media then kind of, looking up and realising that an hour has passed.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So what danger does she mention?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Well, she said that we can get so involved in our phones that we don’t notice the time passing and when we finally look up, we realise that maybe an hour has gone. And I must say, I find that to be true for me, especially when I'm watching videos online. They pull you in with more and more videos and I’ve spent ages just getting lost in video after video.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well that's not a problem if you're looking at our YouTube site, of course - there's lots to see there.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Yes, BBC Learning English, no problem. You can watch as many as you like.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, she talks about checking our phones compulsively . If you do something compulsively you can’t really control it - it’s a feature of being addicted to something, you feel you have to do it again and again. Some tech companies, though, are now looking at building in timers to apps which will warn us when we have spent too long on them. Does Jean Twenge think this will be a good idea?

transcript.author: Jean Twenge, psychologist and author
transcript.text: It might mean that people look at social media less frequently and that they do what it really should be used for, which is to keep in touch with people but then put it away and go see some of those people in person or give them a phone call.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So, does she think it’s a good idea?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Well, she doesn’t say so directly, but we can guess from her answer that she does, because she says these timers will make people spend more time in face-to-face interaction, which a lot of people think would be a good thing.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, she said we should be using it for keeping in touch with people - which means contacting people, communicating with them and also encouraging us to do that communication in person . If you do something in person then you physically do it – you go somewhere yourself or see someone yourself, you don’t do it online or through your smartphone, which nicely brings us back to our quiz question. When was the term smartphone first used in print - 1995, 2000 or 2005? What did you say, Catherine?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: I think I said 2005, without looking it up on my phone, Rob!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: That's good to know, but maybe looking at your phone would have helped because the answer was 1995. But well done to anybody who did know that.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Or well done to anyone who looked it up on their phone and got the right answer.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Mmm, right, before logging off let’s review today’s vocabulary.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: OK, we had FOMO , an acronym that means 'Fear of Missing Out'. Something that I get quite a lot.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And that makes you also a phubber - people who ignore the real people around them because they are concentrating on their phones.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Yes, I do think I’m probably addicted to my phone. I have a psychological and physical need to have it. My smartphone is my drug.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Wow, and you look at it compulsively . You can’t stop looking at it, you do it again and again, don't you?

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: It's sadly true, Rob. To keep in touch with someone is to contact them and share your news regularly.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And if you do that yourself by actually meeting them, then you are doing it in person . And that brings us to the end of today’s programme. Don’t forget you can find us on the usual social media platforms – Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube -  and on our website at bbclearningenglish.com. Bye for now.

transcript.author: Catherine
transcript.text: Bye!
